prior_works.title: OpenMatch: Open-set Consistency Regularization for Semi-Supervised Learning with Outliers
prior_works.role: Open-set semi-supervised learning; combines one-vs-all scoring and confidence/thresholding with consistency to handle unknowns in unlabeled data.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: CWAEE’s one-vs-rest detection of known vs. unknown samples and the use of consistency on unlabeled data directly mirror OpenMatch’s open-set SSL formulation, adapted here to the domain generalization setting.

prior_works.title: DOC: Deep Open Classification
prior_works.authors: Lei Shu, Hu Xu, Bing Liu
prior_works.role: Open-set recognition via one-vs-rest (sigmoid) outputs with per-class rejection thresholds.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: CWAEE operationalizes DOC’s central idea—one-vs-rest decision functions with class-wise thresholds—to detect unknowns among unlabeled samples before exploiting them.

prior_works.title: FlexMatch: Boosting Semi-Supervised Learning with Curriculum
prior_works.role: SSL with class-wise adaptive confidence thresholds to calibrate pseudo-labeling across classes.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: CWAEE’s class-wise adaptive thresholds for filtering known/unknown unlabeled data are inspired by FlexMatch’s per-class thresholding strategy to mitigate class imbalance and calibration issues.

prior_works.title: FixMatch: Simplifying Semi-Supervised Learning with Consistency and Confidence
prior_works.role: Core SSL paradigm using confidence-thresholded pseudo-labels and consistency between weak/strong augmentations.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: CWAEE’s exploitation stage builds on FixMatch-style consistency regularization for unlabeled samples, extending it with domain-shift-aware augmentations.

prior_works.title: Fourier Domain Adaptation for Semantic Segmentation
prior_works.role: Fourier-based amplitude swapping to transfer/style-randomize low-frequency content for robustness across domains.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: CWAEE adopts Fourier-transform-based augmentations to induce style/low-frequency shifts during consistency training, directly leveraging FDA’s insight that frequency-domain perturbations enhance cross-domain generalization.

prior_works.title: Open Set Domain Adaptation by Backpropagation (OSBP)
prior_works.role: Open-set domain adaptation with explicit rejection of unknown target classes via thresholding and separation objectives.
prior_works.relationship_sentence: CWAEE inherits OSBP’s principle that unknowns under domain shift should be detected and rejected rather than aligned, informing its exploration step for unlabeled data in DG.

synthesis_narrative:
CWAEE’s core innovations—detecting unknown classes within unlabeled data and exploiting them via domain-shift-aware consistency—sit at the intersection of open-set learning, semi-supervised learning, and domain generalization. On the exploration side, the method operationalizes the one-vs-rest paradigm with per-class thresholds, a design rooted in open-set recognition. DOC formalized one-vs-rest outputs with class-wise rejection, and CWAEE extends this idea to the SSDG setting where unlabeled data mix known and unknown categories across domains. OpenMatch further bridged open-set assumptions with semi-supervised consistency, showing that combining one-vs-all scoring with confidence control can safely utilize unlabeled data that include outliers; CWAEE generalizes this recipe to DG, grafting in class-level adaptivity. FlexMatch contributes the crucial mechanism of class-wise adaptive thresholds, helping CWAEE calibrate decisions across imbalanced or unevenly learned classes. 
On the exploitation side, CWAEE builds on FixMatch’s simple yet powerful consistency regularization, but replaces generic augmentations with Fourier-based ones inspired by FDA. FDA demonstrated that manipulating low-frequency amplitude alters style while preserving semantics, a property CWAEE leverages to simulate domain shifts during consistency training, thereby improving generalization to unseen domains. Finally, OSBP’s open-set DA perspective motivates explicitly identifying and rejecting unknowns rather than forcing alignment, guiding CWAEE’s exploration-exploitation split. Together, these works directly inform CWAEE’s architectural choices (one-vs-rest), calibration (class-wise thresholds), learning objective (consistency), and augmentation strategy (Fourier), producing a targeted solution to SSDG with unknown classes.
